title: How to use NOR gates to implement the Boolean expressions X=(A+B) (C+D) - Quora

response.answer_text: We know De Morgan's theorem: [math]\overline{X+Y} = \overline{X}.\overline{Y}[/math] So, [math]\overline{\overline{X}+\overline{Y}} = \overline{\overline{X}}.\overline{\overline{Y}}[/math] By theorem of Boolean Algebra, we know that [math]\hspace{1mm} \overline{\overline{X}} = X.[/math] Therefore, [math]\overline{\overline{X}+\overline{Y}} = X.Y[/math] Think of X as (A+B) and Y as (C+D). [math]\overline{\overline{(A+B)}+\overline{(C+D)}} = (A+B).(C+D)[/math] Now recognize that the equation of NOR gate is: [math]Y = \overline{(A+B)}[/math] Use a NOR gate to find [math]\hspace{1mm} \overline{(A+B)}.\hspace{1mm}[/math] Use another NOR gate to find [math]\hspace{1mm} \overline{(C+D)}.\hspace{1mm}[/math] Use another NOR gate to NOR these two outputs to get [math]\hspace{1mm}(A+B).(C+D) \hspace{1mm}[/math] as we have derived it above (by applying De Morgan's theorem).
